unnormalised: IIT Bombay students got a shocker in their Stats 101 midterm! Turns out, calculating the probability of chai spilling on your exam paper is harder than it looks. Apparently, the prof factored in variables like "student nervousness level" and "distance to the nearest samosa," leading to some seriously skewed results.
normalised: I-I-T Bombay students got a shocker in their Stats one hundred and one midterm! Turns out, calculating the probability of chai spilling on your exam paper is harder than it looks. Apparently, the prof factored in variables like "student nervousness level" and "distance to the nearest samosa," leading to some seriously skewed results.

unnormalised: The average score was a measly 45%, leading to cries of foul play. One student, Rakesh, complained, "I could ace JEE but figuring out the standard deviation of getting late to class thanks to Mumbai traffic? Complete bouncer, yaar!" Rumors are swirling that the prof, Dr. Sharma, is actually a disgruntled cricketer who’s using probability to predict when the next India-Pakistan match will *finally* happen.
normalised: The average score was a measly forty five percent, leading to cries of foul play. One student, Rakesh, complained, "I could ace J-E-E but figuring out the standard deviation of getting late to class thanks to Mumbai traffic? Complete bouncer, yaar!" Rumors are swirling that the prof, Doctor Sharma, is actually a disgruntled cricketer who’s using probability to predict when the next India-Pakistan match will *finally* happen.

unnormalised: Adding insult to injury, the bonus question involved calculating the confidence interval for "likelihood of convincing your parents you need a new laptop for 'academic purposes'." No wonder everyone’s prepone-ing their study sessions and drowning their sorrows in extra-large cups of overpriced canteen coffee. Maybe they should teach us how to calculate the probability of passing *this* course!
